articles.headline: New Laws Ban Most Abortions in North Dakota
articles.snippet: Gov. Jack Dalrymple signed the nation’s toughest abortion restrictions into law on Tuesday, including a measure that bans the procedure as soon as six weeks into a pregnancy.
articles.abstract: Gov. Jack Dalrymple signed the nation’s toughest abortion restrictions into law on Tuesday, including a measure that bans the procedure as soon as six weeks into a pregnancy.
articles.lead_paragraph: FARGO, N.D. — Gov. Jack Dalrymple of North Dakota approved the nation’s toughest abortion restrictions on Tuesday, signing into law a measure that would ban nearly all abortions and inviting a legal showdown over just how much states can limit access to the procedure.
articles.byline: By John Eligon and Erik Eckholm

articles.headline: New Prostate Cancer Tests Could Reduce False Alarms
articles.snippet: Sophisticated new tests might supplement unreliable readings of the protein P.S.A., which often detect cancers that are unlikely to cause harm.
articles.abstract: Sophisticated new tests might supplement unreliable readings of the protein P.S.A., which often detect cancers that are unlikely to cause harm.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sophisticated new prostate cancer tests are coming to market that might supplement the unreliable P.S.A. test, potentially saving tens of thousands of men each year from unnecessary biopsies, operations and radiation treatments.

articles.headline: T-Mobile Shakes Up Its Service
articles.snippet: The American mobile carrier, which has struggled against rivals like AT&T and Verizon, will offer the iPhone 5 and other top smartphones without locking in customers for two years.
articles.abstract: The American mobile carrier, which has struggled against rivals like AT&T and Verizon, will offer the iPhone 5 and other top smartphones without locking in customers for two years.
articles.lead_paragraph: T-Mobile USA, long trailing its rivals in the cellphone industry, is trying to catch up by changing the conversation: it is selling the iPhone cheaper than the competition, and most important, customers would not have to sign a contract.

articles.headline: Copyright Ruling Rings With Echo of Betamax
articles.snippet: A 1984 Supreme Court decision to permit home videotaping shaped the evolution of digital media. A ruling last week might have a similar effect.
articles.abstract: A 1984 Supreme Court decision to permit home videotaping shaped the evolution of digital media. A ruling last week might have a similar effect.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before Napster and LimeWire, before Megauploads and the Pirate Bay, media companies’ epic struggle against copying, piracy and generally losing control over their creations can be traced to a legal fight more than 30 years ago over a device that has long since passed on to the great trash heap in the sky: the Sony Betamax.

articles.headline: In Cyprus, Big Losses Expected on Deposits
articles.snippet: International lenders have assumed the country’s economy would shrink 3 percent, but with the chaos of recent weeks it may shrink 5 to 10 percent.
articles.abstract: International lenders have assumed the country’s economy would shrink 3 percent, but with the chaos of recent weeks it may shrink 5 to 10 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — With time running out until Cyprus’s devastated banks must reopen their doors to the public, Cypriot and European officials are scrambling to put in place a set of measures that would allow jittery depositors access to their savings while preventing many billions of euros from fleeing the country.

articles.headline: Firm Is Accused of Sending Spam, and Fight Jams Internet
articles.snippet: A squabble between a group battling spam and a Web hosting company said to be sending it has escalated into an attack clogging up infrastructure worldwide.
articles.abstract: A squabble between a group battling spam and a Web hosting company said to be sending it has escalated into an attack clogging up infrastructure worldwide.
articles.lead_paragraph: A squabble between a group fighting spam and a Dutch company that hosts Web sites said to be sending spam has escalated into one of the largest computer attacks on the Internet, causing widespread congestion and jamming crucial infrastructure around the world.
articles.byline: By John Markoff and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Good Friends, Same Party but Legal Opponents
articles.snippet: Two conservative Republican lawyers, Theodore B. Olson and Charles J. Cooper, argued opposite sides of a historic Supreme Court case.
articles.abstract: Two conservative Republican lawyers, Theodore B. Olson and Charles J. Cooper, argued opposite sides of a historic Supreme Court case.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the conference room at the Justice Department’s august Office of Legal Counsel, portraits of Theodore B. Olson and Charles J. Cooper hang side by side. Both men headed the office under President Ronald Reagan in the 1980s, with Mr. Cooper succeeding Mr. Olson. Both went on to stellar legal careers on the conservative side of Washington’s divided political universe.

articles.headline: JPMorgan Chase Faces Full-Court Press of Federal Investigations
articles.snippet: The issues being investigated range from prior knowledge of the Madoff scam to inadequate prevention of money-laundering.
articles.abstract: The issues being investigated range from prior knowledge of the Madoff scam to inadequate prevention of money-laundering.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the nation’s strongest bank, JPMorgan Chase used to be known for carrying special sway with regulators. Now it increasingly finds itself in the cross hairs of federal authorities.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Justices Cast Doubt on Benefits Ban in U.S. Marriage Law
articles.snippet: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy’s questions on the Defense of Marriage Act suggested he was prepared to side with the court’s four liberal members to strike down a central provision.
articles.abstract: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy’s questions on the Defense of Marriage Act suggested he was prepared to side with the court’s four liberal members to strike down a central provision.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court appeared ready on Wednesday to strike down a central part of a federal law that defines marriage as the union of a man and a woman, as a majority of the justices expressed reservations about the Defense of Marriage Act.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Call to a CNN Host Hints at a Shifting ‘Today’
articles.snippet: An NBC executive is said to have asked Anderson Cooper if he would consider taking Matt Lauer’s job as co-host on the “Today” show, which has slumped in the ratings.
articles.abstract: An NBC executive is said to have asked Anderson Cooper if he would consider taking Matt Lauer’s job as co-host on the “Today” show, which has slumped in the ratings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, it was Jay Leno who learned what NBC imagined his future to be. This week, it is Matt Lauer’s turn in the spotlight.
